ACT
207
Proclamation of a missing or destroyed will
If, independently of the testator's will, the document in which the testator's will was formed has disappeared or has been destroyed, and there is no dispute between the interested parties about the previous existence of that will, about the form in which it was drawn up, about the manner of its disappearance or destruction, as well as about its content, the probate court will listen to all interested persons and present the necessary evidence based on their proposals, and will declare the record according to the provisions that apply to the declaration of a written will.
If the estate, if there was no will, would have belonged to the municipality, that is, the city, the agreement from paragraph 1 of this article on its previous form and content will be valid only if the competent state attorney for the place where the property is located agrees with it.
If among the interested persons there are persons who are not capable of taking care of their rights and interests by themselves, the agreement referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article is valid only with the consent of the authority responsible for guardianship affairs.
